DOC.HEAD: Cranston Calls Off His Wedding, Blames Stress And Media
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Alan Cranston announced Thursday he has called off his plans to marry a 49-year-old woman on Christmas Eve, a spokesman for his office said. The Democratic senator, under intense scrutiny for his role in the Lincoln Savings & Loan scandal, said through a spokesperson that the wedding would be unfair to his fiancee, Cathy Lee Pattiz of Beverly Hills. ``When the press pounced upon us before we filled out the marriage license forms, it became clear to me that this is not an appropriate time to start a marriage and it would not be fair to Cathy to bring her into the middle of a stressful situation, so we will not be married on Dec. 24,'' Cranston said in a prepared statement. Cranston, 75, surprised associates recently by announcing he would marry Pattiz at his sister's home in Los Altos Hills. The marriage would have been the third for Cranston, whose last marriage ended in divorce in May, and the first for Pattiz, an Illinois native who has known Cranton since 1968. No other details of the decision were immediatley available. The couple appeared smiling Tuesday when they posed for photographs while taking out a marriage license in Palo Alto. Cranston is one of five U.S. senators under fire for accepting large contributions from Charles Keating Jr., the conservative Arizona financier who ran Lincoln. In 1987, the five interceded on behalf of Keating with a federal regulator involved in probing Lincoln, which declared bankruptcy last April.
